title: Ethiopia: Stakeholders Interlink to Fight Illegal Trade
text:
Uganda: South Africa to Boost Trade Ties With Uganda By Robel Yohannes 
Strengthening the interlink between relevant stakeholders to intensify the fight against illegal and contraband was highlighted during a consultative meeting held yesterday with the theme: 'The role of stakeholders in stopping contraband and illegal trade'. The meeting organized by Fana Broadcasting Corporate - also saw the presentation of annual report by involved stakeholders. 
Border Administration and Contraband Surveillance Deputy Director with the Ethiopian Revenues & Customs Authority (ERCA) Abebe Abera said that illegal and contraband trade brings damage to the country in the shape of; trade distortion, lose of money in revenue, health problems, while putting the country's peace in danger, among other things. 
He added his organization in collaboration with the Federal Police have established up to 55 control posts by identifying corridors that host heavy contraband flow, while undertaking various programmes to raise awareness within the public on the damaging impact of the situation. Illicit goods that are worth 1.9 billion birr have been confiscated in a preventive action the authority took in collaboration with other relevant stakeholders within five years, added. 
Abebe noted that despite these gains and improvements in the fight against contraband, there are still much work left to do to cause significant blow on the overall illegal trade. Further dwelling on this, he said that lack of strong interlink between relevant stakeholders that eclipses mere interface, and not involving the public more intimately, among other things, need to be remedied in order to boost the national anti-contraband campaign. As a way forward, Abebe suggested the need to bring attitudinal change within the public that would not be accommodate such activities. 
Trade Practice and Consumers Protection Authority Research and Development Directorate Director Nebiyou Belete also stressed the need to augment the link between the relevant authorities, stating that cohesive supervision procedure that also oversee a task-force is needed as the supervision work is loose and cannot be done by one institution alone. He also said that traders in the informal sector should slowly be brought into the fold, as one tool in the fight against illegal trade. 
According to Addis Ababa Trade Bureau Deputy Head Gemechis Melaku his office has caught close to 19 million Birr worth of illicit goods this year in the ten sub-cities of Addis Ababa as part of anti-contraband campaign. 
Presenting Bureau report Gemechis also indicated that as a capital city and centre of commerce, Addis Ababa can negatively or positively impact the national trade and exchange system. "With this mind, we have taken various steps, including the establishment of task force in every sub-city to oversee the combat against illegal trade activities like informal & contraband trade and under-invoicing," he added.
